ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Most of the material we essentially learned in our textbook the night before, and the next day Professor Nakamura would talk about those concepts. It was not exactly a lecture, as she would often call on people to engage and the amount of talking puts it closer to a discussion.
Once a week there was an asynchronous class.
homework online video recordings and worksheets

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In terms of writing, I learned Hiragana, Katakana, and some Kanji characters. I learned conversational Japanese, including how to introduce myself, describing objects/people, and other grammar.  Language classes move much quicker in college compared to high school. I learned that I needed to study more on my own outside of the assigned homework in order to get the most out of the class.

I learned introductory level Japanese, such as Hiragana, Katakana, some Kanji, and basic grammar structures. It's been really long since I learned a new living language (in high school, I took Latin), so I had such a great time!
Previously, I had little to no competency in Japanese, but after only one semester, I am able to hold an elementary conversation in Japanese.
I learned a lot about Japanese language, both reading and writing. Furthermore, we learned much about Japanese culture. Other skills were studying skills, and memorization practices as well.
I learned fundamental Japanese basics including the hiragana and katakana alphabets and beginner kanji. We also practiced beginner conversational skills and studied grammar concepts.
Learned the very basics of Japanese speaking, reading, writing, and listening

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths are the emphasis on conversation (as that is arguably the most important part of using language). I wish there was more time to learn hiragana and katakana; it is especially confusing because we learn one after another and the two systems represent the same sounds depending on context.
The course is very intensive, but it's a great introduction to Japanese language study.
The strengths of this class are the constant interaction between students and the professor. Theres a sense of community in the classroom that only furthers the learning engagement.
The course was organized well some of the exercises we did might have been better in person but that is about it.

Each class was really engaging and helped me learn Japanese at a very rapid pace. The biggest weakness of the course was that we didn't receive any grades for any assignments throughout the entire semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the Flipgrid videos were a great way to introduce students to the material and each other (although I don't know if that is COVID-19 specific). I also don't know if conversation shadowing is COVID-19 specific, but I found that memorizing the conversations before each unit were not particularly helpful. However, I do see the merits of conversation shadowing and letting students get over the initial embarrassment of blundering in a foreign language, so I don't know if that should change.

It would have been a lot more fun to take this class in person, but I still thought it was fun and well organized. 

I hope in future classes (especially in an online setting), there would be Japanese tables as there were in language classes in the regular years.
This course adapted very well to the challenges of covid.

The zoom classes worked really well. They were really engaging,  the constant interaction made it much easier to pay attention and to grasp the language. The weekly asynchronous classes were a nice break from the zoom classes, and they helped me recover and prepare for the zoom classes.
Recoding my own videos for homework and watching my classmates' videos was good practice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because it was really fun overall. Being able to converse, however basically, in a foreign language after one semester is astounding to me.
YES. Please take it if you're interested in Japanese and its culture. This class was probably one of my favorite classes of this year.
I recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning more about Japanese language and culture!

I would recommend this class to another student. While it may have a large workload, you learn a lot both about the Japanese language and the Japanese culture. It also teaches valuable studying skills and time management skills as well. The learning environment was very fun while maintaining productivity as well.
I would recommend it if you are genuinely interested in learning Japanese and willing to do all the work the course involves.
I recommend this class to anyone who wants to learn more about Japanese.

Yes! It's a very good class for learning basic Japanese. There is daily homework, though, so if you are someone who doesn't thrive when you have a lot of homework due everyday (especially in earlier parts of the semester), this could be rough for you.
